para.phrase: WILLIAM A. GLOVER, II, YANN F. BOUCHER, CHRISTINE C. LEE, AND CHERYL L. TARR

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The familyVibrionaceae is presently composed of eleven genera (Aliivibrio, Catenococcus, Echinimonas, Enterovibrio, Grimontia, Paraphotobacterium, Photobacterium, Salinivibrio, Thaumasiovibrio, Veronia, and Vibrio) and well over 110 species with standing in bacterial nomenclature (1). Vibrio is the type genus for the family, and Vibrio cholerae, which includes strains that cause pandemic cholera, is the type species (2). Species that are routinely isolated from human clinical specimens can be found in three genera, including Vibrio (16 species) as well as Photobacterium and Grimontia (one species each from clinical specimens). Phylogenetic investigations indicate that multiple monophyletic clades (separate or distinct groups in a phylogenetic sense) exist within Vibrio, which has led to the reclassification of some species into different genera.

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE VIBRIONACEAE
sect2.para: TheVibrionaceae found in clinical specimens are Gram-negative, facultatively anaerobic, straight, curved, or comma-shaped rods, 0.5 to 0.8 μm in width and 1.4 to 2.6 μm in length, that are catalase and oxidase positive (except Vibrio metschnikovii) (2). Most species are motile by means of sheathed single or multiple polar flagella when grown in liquid media. Strains of some species, such as Vibrio parahaemolyticus and Vibrio alginolyticus, swarm on solid media by production of numerous lateral flagella (2, 3). All Vibrionaceae require Na+ for growth, with the minimal concentration for optimum growth ranging from 0.029 to 4.1% NaCl (2). They ferment D-glucose but rarely produce gas, reduce nitrate to nitrite (except V. metschnikovii), and grow on thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) medium (except Grimontia hollisae). The G+C content of their DNA is 38 to 51 mol% (2). Utilization of the vibriostatic agent O/129 can be helpful in differentiating vibrios from other Gram-negative rods but is no longer widely used.
Key properties or characteristics useful in separating clinically significantVibrionaceae from phylogenetically related or phenotypically similar species are listed in Table 1.

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY, TRANSMISSION, AND CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: The genera covered in this chapter are ubiquitous in aquatic environments, primarily marine waters. Vibrios such asV. cholerae, V. paracholerae, V. tarriae, V. metoecus, and V. mimicus that require minimal amounts of Na+ for growth can be found in freshwater rivers and lakes as well as estuarine and marine environments (4–6). Vibrionaceae are commonly isolated from a variety of bivalves and crustaceans, and like other genera found in marine environments, their concentrations peak during the warmer months of the year. In aquatic environments, vibrios can persist in a free-living state or in association with phytoplankton and zooplankton (7, 8). In the environment, vibrios may enter a state referred to as viable but nonculturable (VBNC), in which cells retain basic metabolic processes even though they fail to grow on standard laboratory media (9). Among the vibrios, the VBNC state is best known in V. cholerae, but it has been demonstrated in other pathogenic Vibrio species, including V. parahaemolyticus, V. mimicus, and V. vulnificus (10). V. cholerae in the VBNC state poses a risk to public health because it can be resuscitated in the human gastrointestinal tract, but detection in water may be unsuccessful if traditional culture methods are used (11).

TheVibrionaceae have been isolated from a wide variety of intestinal and extraintestinal human illnesses. These illnesses include diarrhea, soft tissue disease (cellulitis and necrotizing fasciitis), septicemia, and eye and ear infections (2). Preexisting liver disease is a known risk factor for more severe Vibrio infections and has been associated with elevated serum iron levels, which have been reported to play a role in Vibrio pathogenesis (12, 13). In some cases of gastroenteritis and extraintestinal infections, it may be difficult to determine if a positive Vibrio detection represents true infection or merely colonization, because of its widespread occurrence in marine and estuarine waters. Ten Vibrio species and one species each of Photobacterium and Grimontia occur in clinical specimens and are listed in Table 2 along with their historical phenotypic results and percentages. Three new species closely related to V. cholerae that are difficult to distinguish by phenotypic methods have recently been associated with clinical specimens and are described below. Additional new species also include V. cidicii (14), V. injensis (15), and V. navarrensis (16). Extraintestinal Vibrio infections are frequently associated with traumatic injuries or inapparent exposure to estuarine or marine waters. Primary septicemia may occur after ingestion of raw seafood (oysters) or as a secondary bacteremia subsequent to a wound infection.

Due to the favorable growth ofVibrio populations in warm temperatures within aquatic environments, a considerable amount of focus and attention has centered on the impact of climate change on this group of bacteria. Recent reports have described the expansion of Vibrio species into locations previously believed to be unfavorable, particularly in northern regions of the Northern Hemisphere (17). Accompanying this reported expansion have been reports of increased human infections as well as outbreaks associated with heat waves (17, 18). Reports suggest that global Vibrio infections will continue their upward trend, further highlighting the importance of this group of bacteria, as well as our ability to recognize, diagnose, identify species, and report cases to national surveillance programs.

sect1.title: V. cholerae
sect1.para: V. cholerae is divided into more than 200 serogroups, of which only V. cholerae serogroups O1 and O139 cause large epidemics and pandemic cholera; however, other serogroups can cause severe dehydrating diarrhea (19). Cholera is associated with poor sanitation, and direct contact with contaminated surface water used for drinking, bathing, cooking, and irrigation is a major risk factor (20).

sect1.title: V. cholerae O1
sect1.para: From September 2019 to September 2020, 16 countries reported outbreaks, with more than 450,000 cases of cholera and over 900 deaths reported to the World Health Organization (WHO) (21), with the majority of cases from Yemen (89%). During the past 2 decades, from 2001 through 2021, cholera in Africa has accounted for >50% of the cases worldwide except for two periods in which the Haiti and Yemen outbreaks took place. From 2010 to 2012, an epidemic in Haiti accounted for the majority of cholera cases (22). A total of 795,794 cases of infection and 9,411 deaths were reported in Haiti through December 2016, after which the outbreak waned significantly. The epidemic in Haiti has now been surpassed by the cholera outbreak in Yemen. From October 2016 to April 2021, a total of 2,538,677 cases with 3,997 deaths have been reported (23).

A majority ofV. cholerae O1 infections are asymptomatic, and these undetected infections may serve as an ongoing reservoir in regions where cholera is endemic (24). Severe infections typically result in copious watery diarrhea, with fluid loss reaching 200 ml/kg of body weight/day. If untreated, the patient becomes prostrate with symptoms of severe dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, painful muscle cramps, watery eyes, loss of skin elasticity, and anuria. Dehydration subsequently leads to hypovolemic shock, acidosis, circulatory collapse, and death, even in previously healthy adults (25). In the United States, occasional cases of cholera are seen in travelers returning from regions of the world where cholera is endemic. Traditional therapy consists of fluid replacement by oral rehydration and/or intravenous fluids.

The unique ability ofV. cholerae serogroup O1 to cause this fulminant form of diarrhea is due to the presence of virulence cassette regions and pathogenicity islands on the bacterial chromosome. These regions contain a number of key determinants, including the ctxAB genes, encoding cholera enterotoxin, which is responsible for the large excretion of fluids and electrolytes into the lumen, and the TCP gene cluster, which includes tcpA, the gene that encodes the major protein subunit of the toxin-coregulated pilus (responsible for attachment to the gastrointestinal epithelium) (20). V. cholerae O1 strains are divided into two serotypes, Inaba and Ogawa (a third serotype, Hikojima, is very rarely isolated), and two biotypes, El Tor and classical. The classical biotype caused the sixth pandemic, while the El Tor biotype, which was first isolated in 1905, is the cause of the ongoing seventh pandemic that began in 1961 (20). Recently, new variants of V. cholerae O1 have emerged in Africa and Asia (26). These atypical or hybrid El Tor strains may be more virulent than most El Tor strains based upon projected case fatality rates (27). Hybrid strains differ from prototypical El Tor isolates in that they share some characteristics with the classical biotype (e.g., an El Tor strain may have the classical ctxB gene on its chromosome) (28). These hybrid strains appear to have evolved via lateral gene transfer and recombination events (26).

sect1.title: V. cholerae O139
sect1.para: In 1992, a new serogroup ofV. cholerae, O139 (originally named V. cholerae O139 Bengal), emerged throughout Asia (29). This serogroup probably resulted from the lateral transfer of a novel somatic antigen and capsule from an unknown bacterium to an El Tor strain (29). O139 and O1 strains carry similar virulence factors, including the ctx and tcpA genes (20). Clinical diseases due to O1 and O139 V. cholerae strains are also strikingly similar, except that adults are more frequently affected with O139, since previous infection with V. cholerae O1 is not protective (30). In 2002, strains of serogroup O139 reemerged in Bangladesh, causing an estimated 30,000 cases of cholera, primarily in older patients (30). To date, no cases of V. cholerae O139 infection have been identified in Africa, although it contributes to the burden of cholera in China (31). Three ctx-positive V. cholerae O139 isolates and one ctx-negative V. paracholerae O139 were recently recovered from humans in Bangladesh, including one case of cholera (32).

sect1.title: V. cholerae non-O1, non-O139
sect1.para: Strains ofV. cholerae that do not fall into the O1 or O139 serogroups are designated “non-O1, non-O139” (or simply “non-O1”) and rarely produce cholera toxin. While the diarrhea produced is watery and severe disease is reported, infections are usually milder than typical cholera. Non-O1 strains of V. cholerae that carry cholera toxin genes, such as strains of serogroups O75 and O141, have caused sporadic cases of cholera-like disease in the United States and elsewhere (33, 34). Risk factors for infection appear to be similar to those for other vibrios and include consumption of oysters and other raw or cross-contaminated seafood. In 2011, there was a small outbreak of V. cholerae serogroup O75 infections linked to consumption of raw or lightly cooked oysters from Apalachicola Bay, FL. The diarrheal symptoms were mild, and no cases required rehydration or hospitalization (35). In 2018, a small outbreak with cholera-like symptoms (caused by non-O1 V. cholerae) occurred from the consumption of raw herring eggs on Vancouver Island, Canada (36).

Non-O1 vibrios, in contrast toV. cholerae O1, are associated with extraintestinal infections, such as septicemia and epidural brain abscess (12, 37). People at increased risk of developing non-O1 bacteremia include those with liver disease/cirrhosis or hematologic malignancies (12). The case fatality rate in these patients ranges from 10 to 65% (12, 38). Strains have also been isolated from ears, wounds, the respiratory tract, and urine (39).

sect1.title: V. mimicus
sect1.para: V. mimicus, another nonhalophilic species, is phenotypically similar to V. cholerae except that it does not ferment sucrose. Human isolates are uncommon, but it is recovered from patients with diarrhea, in which it may or may not have a causal role, and is usually associated with consumption of uncooked seafood, particularly raw oysters. Very few strains carry the ctxAB genes and can produce cholera-like symptoms. Symptoms generally include abundant watery diarrhea, vomiting, and severe dehydration. Most descriptions of V. mimicus gastroenteritis involve individual case reports, but a large-scale foodborne outbreak of gastroenteritis was reported in Thailand in 2004 (40). In that outbreak, over 300 people became ill, and rectal swabs collected from 24 patients all yielded V. mimicus. Presumptive causes of this outbreak included freshwater fish, seafood, and seafood soup. In 2010, a small outbreak in Washington State occurred after consumption of crayfish and was attributed to a V. mimicus strain encoding cholera toxin (41).

sect1.title: V. parahaemolyticus
sect1.para: V. parahaemolyticus is the leading cause of bacterial foodborne intestinal infections in Asia and is almost invariably associated with the consumption of raw fish or shellfish (42). In Japan, 50 to 70% of the cases of foodborne diarrhea are due to V. parahaemolyticus. In the United States, it is the Vibrio species most frequently isolated from clinical specimens and is associated primarily with watery diarrhea but also may be isolated from blood, wounds, or other extraintestinal sites (43). Symptoms of V. parahaemolyticus-associated gastroenteritis often include nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, low-grade fever, and chills. Fatalities are extremely rare but can occur in cases of severe dehydration. Rehydration is usually the only treatment needed, but antimicrobial therapy may be beneficial in some instances. An outbreak of gastroenteritis involving 22 passengers aboard a cruise ship was linked to consumption of raw Alaskan oysters (44). A now widely dispersed clone of V. parahaemolyticus, serotype O3:K6, emerged worldwide in 1997 (45). Strains of this serotype caused an unusually high proportion of V. parahaemolyticus foodborne disease outbreaks in Taiwan from 1996 to 1999, which suggests that there is something unusual regarding its ecology, epidemiology, or virulence. Serovariants are strains of other serotypes possessing a genetic and molecular profile identical to the O3:K6 pandemic clone (45). Over 20 serovariants have been described (e.g., O4:K68, O1:K25, and O14:KUT), which along with O3:K6 have continued to spread throughout Asia and to the United States, Canada, Mexico, Russia, France, Italy, Brazil, Chile, Peru, and Mozambique (45).

sect1.title: V. vulnificus
sect1.para: V. vulnificus causes primary septicemia and wound infection and is responsible for more than 90% of deaths due to vibrios in the United States yearly. Primary septicemia has a fatality rate exceeding 50%, even with hospitalization, and occurs predominantly in men over 50 years old (13). Patients usually have predisposing conditions, such as liver disease, immunosuppression, increased serum iron, or other chronic diseases (13, 46). CDC data indicate that >95% of patients consumed raw oysters within 7 days of their infection. Patients typically present with a sudden onset of fever and chills, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. Secondary skin lesions often appear, progressing to bulla formation and necrosis. Endotoxic shock often occurs and can rapidly lead to death. Both blood cultures and biopsy samples (scrapings) from skin lesions are usually positive. V. vulnificus also causes severe wound infections, usually after trauma and exposure to marine animals or the marine environment (13). Wound infections may progress to cellulitis with extensive necrosis (often requiring surgical debridement), myositis, and necrotizing fasciitis that may mimic gas gangrene, as well as to secondary septicemia. The fatality rate for wound infections ranges from 20 to 30%. Three biogroups have now been defined for V. vulnificus (13). Most infections in the United States are due to biogroup 1; biogroup 2 has been isolated principally from diseased eels and from one human wound infection. V. vulnificus biogroup 3 was described in 1999 and has been limited to wound and blood-borne disease in Israeli patients exposed to live tilapia fish grown in aquaculture (13).

sect1.title: V. alginolyticus
sect1.para: V. alginolyticus is very common in the marine ecosystem and is the second most commonly isolated Vibrio species in the United States. It is most frequently isolated from ear specimens and wound infections following seawater exposure according to data collected through the CDC’s Cholera and Other Vibrio Illness Surveillance system (COVIS). A woman was diagnosed with a V. alginolyticus infection after sea bathing in the British Isles and applying an unsterile seaweed dressing to a preexisting wound (47). V. alginolyticus has also been isolated from ocular infections and from infrequent cases of monomicrobial or polymicrobial bacteremia, mostly in immunocompromised people (48, 49). Isolates are occasionally cultured from diarrheal stool (50), but there is no evidence that it actually causes diarrhea.

sect1.title: Photobacterium damselae
sect1.para: P. damselae (formerly V. damsela) is an aggressive pathogen that causes serious life-threatening illnesses. Fatality rates for P. damselae are unknown, but many reports in the literature describe fatal infections, suggesting a fairly high attributable mortality rate (51). Disease syndromes associated with this bacterium include soft tissue infections (cellulitis and necrotizing fasciitis) and bacteremia. Most wound infections develop as indolent processes that progress to more-severe disease within a matter of hours, and vibrios are often not suspected during the initial diagnosis. In addition to antibiotics, medical intervention, including irrigation, fasciotomy, debridement, and sometimes amputation, is often required.

Typically,P. damselae wound infections occur in fishermen and -women and result from penetrating traumas caused by fish fins, fishhooks, or harpoons (51–53). More recently, however, other sources of infection/colonization have been reported for this organism. These include a case of cellulitis in a healthy teenage surfer who sustained a laceration to his hand from his surfboard and a urinary tract infection in a pregnant female who had sexual intercourse in the Caribbean Sea 1 week prior to infection (54, 55).

sect1.title: Vibrio fluvialis and Vibrio furnissii
sect1.para: V. fluvialis appears to cause sporadic cases of diarrhea worldwide, with severe cases of gastroenteritis sometimes linked to bacteremia (56). V. fluvialis was found in 1.1% of patients with diarrhea in Kolkata, India, from 2002 to 2009, but it was the sole pathogen in only 33% of those cases (57). Based on published reports, there appears to be small but increasing incidence of V. fluvialis isolates cultured from extraintestinal sites. These include cases of acute soft tissue infections (cellulitis) associated with cerebritis and bacteremia (58, 59). For many of these systemic infections, some of which have poor outcomes, vibrios are not initially suspected as a cause. They are eventually associated with seafood consumption or exposure to seawater. V. furnissii is rarely isolated from human clinical specimens, but when it is recovered, it is usually from fecal specimens of patients with diarrhea (60). Its causal role is unproven but deserves investigation. A case of bacteremia caused by V. furnissii following ingestion of seafood has been described (61).

sect1.title: Miscellaneous Vibrios and Vibrio-Like Organisms
sect1.para: Vibrio harveyi is an important pathogen of marine fish and invertebrate species. Since 2018, the National Reference Laboratory at CDC has confirmed 16 isolates of V. harveyi (author unpublished data). V. harveyi infections remain rare, with published case reports of human infection associated with water wound exposures, including two recent wound infections, one a mixed infection of P. damselae and V. harveyi (62, 63). There is an anecdotal report of two isolates from blood and gallbladder (clinical history was not available) that were retrospectively identified by rpoB sequencing (64). G. hollisae (formerly Vibrio hollisae) is a halophilic Vibrio-like species associated primarily with moderate to severe cases of diarrhea, sometimes involving bacteremia or hypovolemic shock (65). Most recorded cases of infection involve a history of consumption of seafood, such as oysters. V. metschnikovii is frequently isolated from freshwater and brackish and marine waters. It was first reported to cause peritonitis and bacteremia in a patient with an inflamed gallbladder. Since then, it has been isolated from additional patients with bacteremia and, rarely, from wound infections; it has also been isolated from cases of cholecystitis, diarrhea, and pneumonia (66, 67). Vibrio cincinnatiensis was first isolated from a patient with bacteremia and meningitis. Subsequent isolates have been recovered from the stool of a person with diarrhea and two aborted bovine fetuses (68). The Washington State Department of Health confirmed its first fatal case of this organism from the blood of a patient with rapidly progressing cellulitis, bacteremia, and septic shock in 2016. A novel species closely related to V. metschnikovii and V. cincinnatiensis, named Vibrio injensis, was recently identified in human clinical specimens in South Korea; however, its pathogenic potential is unclear (15). CDC has observed five additional Vibrio species that have occasionally been isolated from human clinical specimens. Three species, Vibrio metoecus (6), V. paracholerae (4) and V. tarriae (5), are closely related to V. cholerae. Like their close relative, they are sucrose positive and nonhalophilic. Vibrio navarrensis is a halophilic species first isolated from sewage (69). The CDC used rpoA sequencing and phylogenetic analysis (70) to identify 15 human isolates collected since 1983 as V. navarrensis (71). A species closely related to V. navarrensis, Vibrio cidicii, was recently described (14). Like V. navarrensis, V. cidicii has been isolated from freshwater environments and from cases of diarrhea and extraintestinal infections, but its causative role in disease requires additional investigation.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Pertinent clinical histories (when known) should accompany specimens to alert the laboratory to include appropriate isolation media for theVibrionaceae in their stool workup; this is especially important in areas where the isolation of Vibrio is infrequent (72). Helpful information includes history of travel, consumption of raw shellfish and other seafood, activity associated with marine or brackish water (or wounds associated with such exposure), and hobbies associated with aquaria.

Vibrionaceae are particularly susceptible to drying, so stool specimens that cannot be inoculated onto plating media within 2 to 4 h should be placed in a transport medium. Cary-Blair or any noninhibitory transport medium is acceptable for Vibrio isolation. For specimens collected in the field, if necessary, liquid stool may be placed on strips of blotting paper or gauze and then inserted in airtight plastic bags with a few drops of saline to maintain moisture and sent to the laboratory. Detailed information on the collection and transport of specimens for Vibrio isolation is available elsewhere (73). Special methods for the collection and processing of extraintestinal specimens (blood, wounds, etc.) for Vibrio isolation are not required, as Vibrio organisms are, as a rule, isolated in pure culture from these sites and the concentration of salt in primary plating media is usually sufficient for their recovery. Upon isolation, however, salt may need to be added to subsequent media to attain growth of salt-requiring vibrios. Vibrionaceae may die within weeks in vitro, even in moist environments at room temperature, and should be maintained at −70°C in tryptic soy broth with 15% glycerol as directed in chapter 13 of this Manual.

sect2.title: DIRECT EXAMINATION
sect2.para: Direct microscopic detection of vibrios in stool is not routinely recommended, since it may not be possible to distinguish pathogenic vibrios from other members of the enteric microbiota.

sect1.title: Direct Detection of V. cholerae O1 in Stool
sect1.para: Direct detection ofV. cholerae from stool is typically conducted only in laboratories in areas where cholera is epidemic or endemic or in field situations where laboratory services are unavailable and rapid diagnosis is required. One of the oldest assays, the microscopic immobilization test, detects loss of motility of V. cholerae O1 organisms by the addition of O1 antibody and can be used to detect V. cholerae O139 by using O139 antibody. Two membrane antigen rapid tests, Smart Cholera O1 (sensitivity, 83%; specificity, 88%) and Bengal Smart O139 (sensitivity, 100%; specificity, 97%), are available from New Horizons Diagnostics Corp. (Columbia, MD). Two rapid immunochromatographic dipstick assays, which detect the presence of V. cholerae O1 or O139 antigens in stool, are commercially available from Span Diagnostics (Surat, India) and Standard Diagnostics (Kyonggi-do, South Korea). The Span Crystal Vc for O1 and O139 demonstrated a sensitivity of 92% and a specificity of 73% (74). For the SD Bioline Cholera Ag O1/O139 test (Abbott, Abbot Park, IL), the manufacturer claims a sensitivity of 100% for the O1 antigen and 100% for O139, with respective specificities of 100% and 100%. During an outbreak in Zambia, a study demonstrated a sensitivity of 91% and specificity of 95% (75).

sect1.title: Molecular Detection in Clinical Specimens
sect1.para: Publications on molecular methodologies for detection ofV. cholerae, V. parahaemolyticus, and V. vulnificus specifically in stool can be found in the literature starting in the 1990s and are too numerous to cover here. Few of these tests are commercially available. Most of the advantages of PCR-based assays over culture methods apply to vibrios and include the ability to freeze stool samples for epidemiological studies for delayed testing. In areas where vibrios are rarely isolated and laboratory experience or resources are limited, molecular methods may be more practical and provide reliable results than culture with a shorter turnaround time. Inhibitors in stool may affect the analytical sensitivity of a PCR assay but can be overcome by dilution of the sample. Laboratory-developed nucleic acid amplification tests for V. cholerae use a multiplex PCR that includes primers for the ctxA gene, rfb genes (O antigens O1 and O139, allowing differentiation of serotypes), and tcpA genes (specific for the El Tor and classical biotypes); co-occurrence of these three genes can be interpretable as the El Tor or classical biotype (76, 77). For clinical strains of V. parahaemolyticus, the thermostable direct hemolysin, a major virulence determinant, is a common target for detection, but it is not universally present in strains isolated from human infections (78, 79).

Commercially available syndromic gastrointestinal panels offer detection of vibrios from stool. Currently, FDA-cleared assays include the Verigene enteric pathogen test (Verigene EP; Luminex Corporation), the Luminex xTAG gastrointestinal pathogen panel (Luminex GPP; Luminex Corporation), the BioFire FilmArray gastrointestinal panel (BioFire GIP; bioMérieux), BD Max extended enteric bacterial panel (BD Max xEBP; BD), and the Applied BioCode gastrointestinal panel (BioCode GPP; Applied BioCode) (80). Depending on the assay, unpreserved stool or stool samples preserved in Cary-Blair medium undergo PCR-based pathogen detection, with a time to result of 1 to 5 h. It is important to note that these panels vary in detecting a limited number of clinically relevant Vibrio species (V. cholerae, V. parahaemolyticus, and Vibrio vulnificus) they can detect and differentiate (Table 3). The use of commercial syndromic GI panels has increased steadily since FDA clearance of these testing methods in 2014 (FoodNet Fast, CDC). The greater sensitivity from utilization of syndromic GI panels does present certain challenges with regard to result interpretation for vibrios which represent lower-prevalence pathogens on these panels. Viable and nonviable organisms as well as transient nucleic acid can all be detected by these assays, highlighting the importance of clinical context in interpretation (81). False-positive results have been described for vibrios (82) as well as a low rate of culture confirmation, that is, recovery of Vibrio isolates from reflexed positive specimens (83). Current explanations for discrepancies between positive panel results and culture recovery that have been described for vibrios include low levels of organisms, cross-reactivity with other organisms, and low levels of contaminating nucleic acid introduced into Cary-Blair medium, reagents, or samples during the manufacturing or testing process (BioFire technical note FLM1-PRT-0239-03). When feasible, laboratories should attempt to culture confirm positive Vibrio results from GI syndromic panels.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Vibrionaceae associated with human disease can be isolated from routine enteric media, but recovery is enhanced when specific media are used. On MacConkey or Salmonella-Shigella agar, vibrios (with the exception of the rapidly lactose-fermenting strains of V. vulnificus) present as colorless colonies. Some strains of V. cholerae are inhibited on MacConkey and Salmonella-Shigella agar. On sucrose-containing media, such as Hektoen agar and xylose-lysine-deoxycholate (XLD), sucrose-positive vibrios associated with human disease, such as V. cholerae, V. fluvialis, V. alginolyticus, and some strains of V. vulnificus, cannot be differentiated from strains of other enteric bacteria that rapidly ferment sucrose. The addition of a blood agar plate allows colonies to be screened for oxidase, which may improve the recovery of vibrios as well as colonies of Aeromonas species and Plesiomonas shigelloides. G. hollisae may grow poorly or not at all on any enteric isolation medium, including TCBS medium; it is probably most reliably isolated from blood agar.

TCBS agar is formulated specifically for the isolation of vibrios (2). Both powdered formulations and prepared plates are available from a number of commercial sources. Inclusion of sucrose allows preliminary differentiation of Vibrio species, with V. cholerae, V. metoecus, V. paracholerae, V. tarriae, V. fluvialis, and V. alginolyticus producing yellow colonies, while V. parahaemolyticus, V. mimicus, and most strains of V. vulnificus produce green colonies (sucrose is not fermented). It should be noted that yellow colonies may convert to green if plates are examined after more than 24 h or are refrigerated after incubation. Oxidase testing is unreliable when performed directly on colonies growing on this medium. Growth from a non-sugar-containing medium, such as blood or nutrient agar, should be used for oxidase testing.

A chromogenic agar, CHROMagarVibrio (CHROMagar Microbiology, Paris, France), has been developed primarily for the recovery of V. parahaemolyticus from seafood and supports the growth of other vibrios as well (84). Vibrio colonies on this medium range in color from milk white to pale blue to violet. Other members of the enteric microbiota usually do not grow, with the exception of Proteus mirabilis and Providencia rettgeri, which also produce milk white colonies. Marine agar (BD Biosciences, Sparks, MD), which does not contain any inhibitory or selective ingredients, may be more appropriate for isolation of vibrios from the environment, especially salt-requiring vibrios, because of its high salt content.

It is common for pure cultures of vibrios to produce multiple colony morphologies (as many as five) on any medium, but this phenomenon is most readily noticeable on nonselective media, such as blood and heart infusion agars. Variations in morphology include smooth, rough, convex, flat, spreading, and compact cells in various combinations. Occasionally,V. cholerae produces rugose (extremely wrinkled) colonies on non-carbohydrate-containing media (85). Like their smooth counterparts, they are fully virulent for humans (86). Rugosity, which is due to production of a unique extracellular polysaccharide, confers biofilm formation and resistance to chlorine, acid pH, and serum killing (85, 86). Although it is believed to enhance survival in aquatic environments, to date it has been demonstrated only in vitro. Isolates of the classical biotype of V. cholerae also possess the vps (vibrio polysaccharide synthesis) gene cluster, which encodes this phenotype, but rugose variants have been demonstrated only from El Tor strains (86).

In acute diarrheal disease, stool enrichment is generally not required; however, when enrichment is necessary, alkaline peptone water (1% NaCl, pH 8.5) is the most commonly used enrichment broth for human specimens. It should be incubated at 36°C and subcultured at 6 h and 18 h on TCBS medium.

sect1.title: Conventional Phenotypic Tests
sect1.para: Phenotypic properties that separate members of theVibrionaceae from the Enterobacterales and the Aeromonadaceae are found in Table 1, and historical phenotypic profiles of 12 species that occur in human clinical specimens are given in Table 2. Newer Vibrio species (V. paracholerae, V. tarriae, V. metoecus, V. cidicii, V. navarrensis, and V. injensis) more recently identified from clinical specimens are omitted from this table, as only a limited number of phenotypically characterized isolates are available. Additionally, conventional phenotypic methods alone are not sufficient to identify all of these species. Many commercial standard tube tests have sufficient salt to support growth without salt supplementation (0.5 to 1%), but some tests—such as the Voges-Proskauer test, Moeller’s test for decarboxylases and dihydrolase, and the nitrate broth test—may contain no NaCl or insufficient NaCl to support the growth of some NaCl-requiring strains, and these tests’ media should always have salt added to them (to a final concentration of 1%).

It should be noted that manyV. cholerae O1 strains from Bangladesh and surrounding areas and all strains of V. cholerae O139 are resistant to both 10- and 150-μg disks of the vibriostatic compound O/129 (Remel, Lenexa, KS), a test historically used to distinguish vibrios (Table 1). In areas of the world where cholera is uncommon, all cultures identified as V. cholerae should be sent to public health laboratories for further characterization, including O1 and O139 agglutination and nucleic acid amplification tests for the presence of the ctxA and tcpA genes (or in silico detection of these characteristics from genome sequences). Traditionally, El Tor biotypes have been differentiated by a number of phenotypic tests, including hemolysis of sheep erythrocytes, production of acetylmethylcarbinol (Voges-Proskauer test), and resistance to polymyxin B (26). Except in their serogroup and O/129 reactions, V. cholerae O139 strains are phenotypically similar to V. cholerae O1 El Tor strains. Strains of V. cholerae that fail to agglutinate in either O1 or O139 antiserum are reported as V. cholerae non-O1. Serogrouping for non-O1 strains is available in a limited number of reference laboratories, which typically use only some of many possible sera.

V. cholerae, V. metoecus, V. paracholerae, V. tarriae, and V. mimicus are distinguished from other species by growth in media lacking NaCl (Difco, BD Biosciences; nutrient broth may be the only broth that accurately determines NaCl requirement). Strains of V. parahaemolyticus, V. alginolyticus, and P. damselae may be urea positive. Most vibrios isolated from humans produce a buff or tan pigment; however, strains of V. parahaemolyticus may produce a dark-brown pigment. G. hollisae generally grows poorly, especially in Moeller’s decarboxylase and dihydrolase broths, even after salt supplementation, and produces extremely large zones of inhibition, often necessitating the use of two plates when disk diffusion antimicrobial susceptibility testing is performed. V. metschnikovii is distinctive because it is an oxidase- and nitrate-negative Vibrio sp. V. fluvialis and V. furnissii are frequently confused with Aeromonas caviae (synonym Aeromonas punctata), especially because some strains are weakly halophilic and only moderately susceptible to O/129, and because some strains of A. caviae grow on TCBS agar. V. furnissii is the only Vibrio isolated from humans that is positive for gas production from D-glucose. Rapid, correct identification of V. vulnificus strains is critical because of the mortality associated with this organism. Some strains of V. vulnificus are sucrose positive, which may add to the confusion in identifying it. The phenotypic characteristics of V. navarrensis and V. cidicii are similar to those of V. vulnificus, except for the notable difference of negative test results for ornithine and lysine decarboxylase (71). V. cidicii can be differentiated from V. navarrensis by its utilization of L-rhamnose (14).

sect1.title: Commercial Systems
sect1.para: There are no recent studies evaluating commercial systems’ abilities to identify organisms covered in this chapter; however, identification of these organisms by commercial systems is problematic. Commercial systems are constantly changing and updating their databases, so the reader is urged to consult current information about the status of the database. One evaluation that compared six commercial systems (87) indicated that when tested only against species listed in their databases, API 20E (bioMérieux, Inc., Durham, NC), Crystal E/NF (BD Biosciences), MicroScan Neg ID type 2 and type 3 (Siemens Healthcare Systems, West Sacramento, CA), and Vitek GNI+ and ID-GNB cards (bioMérieux) correctly identified only 63 to 81% of these organisms to the species level. Correct identifications of three commonly isolated species of Vibrio from clinical samples varied. For V. cholerae, API 20E gave the least (50%) and Crystal E/NF the most (97%) accurate identification. For V. parahaemolyticus, Rapid Neg ID3 fared the worst (40%) and API 20E and GNI+ the best (97% each), while for V. vulnificus biogroup 1 strains, GNI+ (50%) and Crystal E/NF (97%) gave the lowest and highest rates, respectively. Only Crystal E/NF was able to correctly identify ≥90% of V. cholerae or V. vulnificus strains, and only API 20E and the two Vitek cards correctly identified ≥90% of V. parahaemolyticus strains. In another study using only V. vulnificus biotype 3 strains, the MicroScan (98%) and Phoenix (90%) systems did the best in identifying 51 well-characterized isolates to the correct species, while the identification rate with Vitek (14%) was much less satisfactory (86). Croci et al. (88) found that for the identification of V. parahaemolyticus, API 20NE exhibited greater sensitivity than API 20E (20 versus 16 of 27 specimens) but API 20E was more specific (100% versus 82%). In another study of a mixture of 111 clinical and environmental V. vulnificus strains, API 20E, API 20NE, and Biolog (Biolog, Inc., Hayward, CA) correctly identified 60, 0, and 85% of strains, respectively (89). Manufacturers’ instructions should be checked prior to testing of salt-requiring vibrios to determine if salt supplementation is required. One publication indicated that API 20E gave incorrect identifications for clinical isolates of V. parahaemolyticus if 2.0% NaCl was used for the diluent, versus 0.85% (88).

sect1.title: Molecular Methods
sect1.para: Species-level identification of many of the less common and newer vibrios requires the utilization of molecular methods that offer advantages over traditional phenotypic methods. Various molecular approaches used to differentiateVibrio species are described in the literature. The use of 16S rRNA gene sequencing alone is less than ideal for Vibrionaceae identification, because interspecies sequence differences can be very small and polymorphism has been shown to be fairly common in 16S rRNA genes (90). Tarr et al. (64) developed a multiplex PCR assay, using primers directed at V. cholerae sodB, V. mimicus sodB, V. parahaemolyticus flaE, and V. vulnificus hsp genes, that correctly identified 109 isolates and found an additional 4 strains of V. parahaemolyticus that either had not been identified to the species level (n = 3) or had been identified incorrectly as V. alginolyticus (n = 1). Additionally, rpoB gene sequencing has been used to identify 12 of 15 isolates not previously identified to the species level by phenotypic methods and led to the discovery of V. cidicii (14) and V. metoecus (6). V. paracholerae was first identified by sequencing of the viuB gene (4), which also provides subspecies resolution for V. cholerae and can distinguish O1/O139 pandemic strains from other lineages (6). Multilocus sequence analysis using rpoA, recA, and pyrH gene segments has also been shown to cluster Vibrio species into distinct groups that are roughly consistent with established taxonomy (70). Methods that assess genetic relatedness from genome sequences, either through phylogenetic analysis (91) or genotypic analyses, such as average nucleotide identity (92) and digital DNA-DNA hybridization (93), will likely replace traditional workflows to identify species in the near future. When combined with core genome multilocus sequence typing (cgMLST) or phylogenetic analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms, genome sequencing also enables identification and characterization of bacterial isolates to the level of subtyping that is useful for outbreak investigations with a single workflow (94).

Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) has become a valuable tool for rapid identification of closely related bacterial species, with a rapid turnaround time and modest test cost. MALDI-TOF MS produced phylogenetic classification results comparable to those ofrpoB sequencing for Vibrio species (95). A multicenter evaluation of the Vitek MS v.2.0 (bioMérieux) (96) included only the three commonly isolated species (V. parahaemolyticus, V. vulnificus, and V. cholerae) and correctly identified about 90% of the isolates within each species. Data are limited on the performance of MALDI-TOF MS for less commonly encountered species (e.g., V. metschnikovii) and for close relatives (e.g., V. alginolyticus and V. mimicus) of the three common species. V. parahaemolyticus and V. vulnificus are in the FDA-cleared databases of both the Bruker Biotyper CA (Bruker Daltonics, Billerica, MA) and Vitek MS systems. However, it should be noted that V. cholerae is also in the FDA-cleared Vitek MS database but is currently not in the main spectrum database of the Bruker Biotyper. Additionally, newly characterized species, which include V. paracholerae, V. tarriae, V. metoecus, V. cidicii, and V. injensis, are absent from current databases. Laboratories using MALDI-TOF MS systems in the routine identification of vibrios should be well versed in which species are included in the database version being utilized as well as differences between databases (research use only [RUO] versus FDA cleared) within and between systems (Biotyper versus Vitek MS). When evaluating Vibrio species in MALDI-TOF MS databases, it is recommended that species-level identification be validated by an alternative method prior to accepting identifications for clinical use.

sect1.title: V. cholerae and V. parahaemolyticus Toxin Detection
sect1.para: Historically, reference laboratories detected cholera toxin by fluid accumulation in animal assays or detection of a cytopathic effect in Y1 adrenal or Chinese hamster ovary cell cultures. A reverse passive latex agglutination (VET-RPLA) assay (Denka Seiken) which detects both cholera toxin and the heat-labile toxin ofEscherichia coli is commercially available. It is now more common to screen isolates for the presence of the ctxA gene using multiplex PCR (76, 77). A majority of human strains of V. parahaemolyticus produce a thermostable direct hemolysin encoded by two genes, tdh and tdh2x. These toxins are rarely produced by environmental strains of V. parahaemolyticus but have been detected in V. cholerae non-O1, V. mimicus, and G. hollisae strains. Like cholera toxin, thermostable direct hemolysin can be detected by a commercial latex assay (KAP-RPLA; Denka Seiken), but there are no commercial products that detect the related thermostable hemolysin (trh) seen in V. parahaemolyticus. PCR assays for cholera toxin genes and both V. parahaemolyticus hemolysins have been developed but are not commercially available (97).

sect1.title: Serotyping
sect1.para: Serotyping is still used for subtyping ofV. cholerae and is routinely performed in public health laboratories; however, serotyping of V. parahaemolyticus is rarely performed today. Typing schemes have been described for a number of species, including V. cholerae, V. parahaemolyticus, and V. vulnificus; however, commercial typing sera are available only for V. cholerae and V. parahaemolyticus. V. cholerae O1 (polyclonal, Inaba and Ogawa) and O139 antisera are available from BD Biosciences, Denka Seiken, Remel, and New Horizons. V. parahaemolyticus antisera (11 O groups and 9 polyvalent and 65 monovalent K groups) are available from Denka Seiken.

sect1.title: Molecular Typing of Vibrios
sect1.para: Traditionally, methods such as pulsed-field gel electrophoresis using NotI and SfiI enzymes were standardized approaches to molecular typing of vibrios for surveillance purposes (98, 99). For V. vulnificus, repetitive extragenic palindromic PCR is an effective subtyping method (100). Genotyping systems based on nucleotide sequence polymorphisms in several genes (16S rRNA gene, vvhA, and vcg) were originally thought to distinguish clinical from environmental isolates, but these methods do not clearly differentiate pathogenic from nonpathogenic strains of V. vulnificus (89). Phylogenetic analysis of housekeeping genes has revealed two distinct lineages of V. vulnificus, with both environmental and clinical isolates falling into each of the lineages (100). MLST has been useful in resolving the population structure of V. parahaemolyticus strains in the northwestern United States and elsewhere, and the technique allows identification of the pandemic clone (101). In addition to V. parahaemolyticus, MLST schemes are available for the other two commonly isolated species (V. cholerae and V. vulnificus) (http://www.pubmlst.org). All of these subtyping methods are being replaced by whole-genome sequencing and in silico analysis of traditional epidemiological markers (94). A core genome MLST method has been developed for V. parahaemolyticus (101) and V. cholerae (102), which provides the level of discrimination needed for outbreak investigation. Phylogenetic analysis of single nucleotide polymorphisms extracted from whole-genome sequencing in V. cholerae has revealed at least 11 introductions of V. cholerae O1 from Asia into Africa since 1970, causing epidemics that have lasted up to 28 years (103). Similar genomic analyses were also crucial in showing that the cholera epidemic in Haiti resulted from a single introduction from an outside source, most likely Nepal (104, 105). Genomic analyses also show that the sublineage which led to the 2016 Yemen epidemic originated from South Asia and that it caused outbreaks in East Africa before appearing in Yemen (106).

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: Reagents for the serodiagnosis of cholera are available only in specialized reference laboratories, but titration of acute- and convalescent-phase sera in agglutination, vibriocidal, or antitoxin tests is considered reliable (107).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: Generally, for mostV. cholerae and V. parahaemolyticus gastrointestinal infections, treatment by rehydration is recommended over antimicrobial therapy and has the added benefit of reducing the risk of antimicrobial resistance. Antimicrobial therapy, however, can reduce the duration of diarrhea, the duration of shedding of the organism, and the volume of rehydration fluid needed for recovery, and patients are often treated before culture results are known (34). Dehydration due to cholera can result in death within hours, so the choice of antibiotic has to be made based on known prevalence of resistance among circulating strains (108). Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) document M45 (3rd edition) (109) includes susceptibility testing guidelines for noncholera vibrios; CLSI interpretive guidelines are limited to ampicillin, tetracyclines, folate pathway inhibitors, and chloramphenicol for V. cholerae. An integrative genetic element designated the SXT element that carries genes encoding resistance to sulfamethoxazole, trimethoprim, chloramphenicol, and streptomycin emerged first in V. cholerae O139 strains in India and is now seen in O1, non-O1, and O139 cholera strains and V. fluvialis (110). Since 2005, most outbreak isolates of V. cholerae from Asia and Africa have been resistant to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and nalidixic acid (108). Ahmed et al. (110) reported a V. fluvialis isolate with the SXT element and a novel aminoglycoside acetyltransferase gene encoding resistance to gentamicin; resistance to ampicillin, furazolidone, and nalidixic acid was also reported. Multidrug-resistant strains of V. fluvialis have also been noted among other strains from India (57). The non-V. cholerae vibrios generally do not show resistance to most antimicrobial agents except for ampicillin: 53% of Vibrio isolates and 97% of V. alginolyticus isolates monitored by the National Antimicrobial Resistance Monitoring System from 2014 to 2018 showed resistance to ampicillin (111). The fluoroquinolones alone or the synergistic combination of ciprofloxacin and cefotaxime shows excellent in vitro activity against V. vulnificus strains (112, 113).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Isolation ofV. cholerae O1 or O139 should be reported immediately to the health care provider because of the severe dehydration that cholera can produce. The case should also be phoned to public health authorities and the isolate sent to a public health laboratory for confirmation and toxin testing.

When vibrios are isolated from blood or cerebrospinal fluid (bacteremia and meningitis are associated with high mortality rates) or wound infections, which cause extensive tissue damage (V. vulnificus and P. damselae), results should also be phoned immediately to the patient’s health care provider so that rapid and appropriate antibiotic therapy can be initiated. This is especially true for V. vulnificus infections, which have a high mortality rate without rapid, appropriate intervention. The clinical significance of Vibrio species (V. mimicus, V. alginolyticus, G. hollisae, V. harveyi, and V. metschnikovii) in other specimens, particularly stool, may be more difficult to determine and requires prompt consultation with the health care provider to better understand the clinical context. Most health care providers are not familiar with many Vibrionaceae species, and a phone consultation would be mutually beneficial to the laboratory and the patient’s direct health care provider. Information helpful to the health care provider includes the presence or absence of other pathogens and the relative amount of growth (pure or almost pure culture) of the Vibrio species. Vibrionaceae isolates should also be submitted to public health laboratories, because they are monitored under the CDC’s COVIS system; they may also be needed for subtyping.

Vibrionaceae species that are known to cause diarrhea should be considered clinically significant, particularly if they are present in large numbers and no other potential pathogens are present. Isolation of vibrios from stool in small numbers may reflect only transitory colonization; however, species such as V. cholerae, V. mimicus, and V. parahaemolyticus have documented virulence factors that correlate with their ability to cause intestinal infections. Laboratory tests helpful in determining pathogenic potential are available primarily in reference laboratories. Vibrionaceae isolation from sites such as the ears may represent infection, transient colonization, or merely their presence after exposure to seawater. Again, isolation of Vibrionaceae requires prompt consultation with the patient’s health care provider to better understand the clinical context, which can help direct the need for further laboratory investigations.

Finally, readers should be cautioned that misidentification ofVibrio species and their relatives can be a problem in the literature unless investigators used methods that are able to differentiate all of the species in the family Vibrionaceae.
